segment.source: 1 Introduction
segment.target: 1 Introduction

segment.source: A fundamental assumption about information security is that a system can identify who is using it.
segment.target: A fundamental assumption about information security is that a system can identify who is using it.

segment.source: Identifying a user allows the system to decide whether the user is identified appropriately (a process known as authentication), and then decide what a properly authenticated user should be able to do (authorization).
segment.target: Identifying a user allows the system to decide whether the user is identified appropriately (a process known as authentication), and then decide what a properly authenticated user should be able to do (authorization).

segment.source: The overwhelming majority of computer systems deployed throughout the world depend on user credentials for making authentication and authorization decisions, which means that these systems depend on reusable, user-created passwords as the basis for their security.
segment.target: The overwhelming majority of computer systems deployed throughout the world depend on user credentials for making authentication and authorization decisions, which means that these systems depend on reusable, user-created passwords as the basis for their security.

segment.source: The oft-cited maxim that authentication can involve "something you know, something you have, or something you are" neatly highlights the issue: a reusable password is an authentication factor all by itself, so anyone who knows the password can impersonate the user who owns it.
segment.target: The oft-cited maxim that authentication can involve "something you know, something you have, or something you are" neatly highlights the issue: a reusable password is an authentication factor all by itself, so anyone who knows the password can impersonate the user who owns it.

segment.source: 1.1 Problems with traditional credentials
segment.target: 1.1 Problems with traditional credentials

segment.source: Ever since the mid-1960s, when Fernando Corbató and his team at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology championed the introduction of the password, users and administrators have had to deal with the use of passwords for user authentication and authorization.
segment.target: Ever since the mid-1960s, when Fernando Corbató and his team at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology championed the introduction of the password, users and administrators have had to deal with the use of passwords for user authentication and authorization.

segment.source: Over time, the state of the art for password storage and use has advanced somewhat (with secure hashing and salting, for example), but we are still faced with two problems.
segment.target: Over time, the state of the art for password storage and use has advanced somewhat (with secure hashing and salting, for example), but we are still faced with two problems.

segment.source: Passwords are easy to clone and they are easy to steal.
segment.target: Passwords are easy to clone and they are easy to steal.

segment.source: In addition, implementation faults may render them insecure, and users have a hard time balancing convenience and security.
segment.target: In addition, implementation faults may render them insecure, and users have a hard time balancing convenience and security.

segment.source: 1.1.1 Credential theft
segment.target: 1.1.1 Credential theft

segment.source: The biggest risk of passwords is simple: an attacker can steal them easily.
segment.target: The biggest risk of passwords is simple: an attacker can steal them easily.

segment.source: Every place a password is entered, processed, or stored is vulnerable.
segment.target: Every place a password is entered, processed, or stored is vulnerable.

segment.source: For example, an attacker can steal a collection of passwords or hashes from an authentication server by eavesdropping on network traffic to an application server, by implanting malware in an application or on a device, by logging user keystrokes on a device, or by watching to see which characters a user types.
segment.target: For example, an attacker can steal a collection of passwords or hashes from an authentication server by eavesdropping on network traffic to an application server, by implanting malware in an application or on a device, by logging user keystrokes on a device, or by watching to see which characters a user types.

segment.source: These are just the most common attack methods.
segment.target: These are just the most common attack methods.

segment.source: Another related risk is that of credential replay, in which an attacker captures a valid credential by eavesdropping on an insecure network, and then replays it later to impersonate a valid user.
segment.target: Another related risk is that of credential replay, in which an attacker captures a valid credential by eavesdropping on an insecure network, and then replays it later to impersonate a valid user.

segment.source: Most authentication protocols (including Kerberos and OAuth) protect against replay attacks by including a time stamp in the credential exchange process, but that tactic only protects the token that the authentication system issues, not the password that the user provides to get the ticket in the first place.
segment.target: Most authentication protocols (including Kerberos and OAuth) protect against replay attacks by including a time stamp in the credential exchange process, but that tactic only protects the token that the authentication system issues, not the password that the user provides to get the ticket in the first place.

segment.source: 1.1.2 Credential reuse
segment.target: 1.1.2 Credential reuse

segment.source: The common approach of using an email address as the username makes a bad problem worse.
segment.target: The common approach of using an email address as the username makes a bad problem worse.

segment.source: An attacker who successfully recovers a username–password pair from a compromised system can then try that same pair on other systems.
segment.target: An attacker who successfully recovers a username–password pair from a compromised system can then try that same pair on other systems.

segment.source: This tactic works surprisingly often to allow attackers to springboard from a compromised system into other systems.
segment.target: This tactic works surprisingly often to allow attackers to springboard from a compromised system into other systems.

segment.source: The use of email addresses as usernames leads to additional problems that we will explore later in this guide.
segment.target: The use of email addresses as usernames leads to additional problems that we will explore later in this guide.

segment.source: 1.2 Solving credential problems
segment.target: 1.2 Solving credential problems

segment.source: Solving the problems that passwords pose is tricky.
segment.target: Solving the problems that passwords pose is tricky.

segment.source: Tightening password policies alone will not do it; users may just recycle, share, or write down passwords.
segment.target: Tightening password policies alone will not do it; users may just recycle, share, or write down passwords.

segment.source: Although user education is critical for authentication security, education alone does not eliminate the problem either.
segment.target: Although user education is critical for authentication security, education alone does not eliminate the problem either.

segment.source: Microsoft Passport replaces passwords with strong two-factor authentication (2FA) by verifying existing credentials and by creating a device-specific credential that a biometric or PIN-based user gesture protects.
segment.target: Microsoft Passport replaces passwords with strong two-factor authentication (2FA) by verifying existing credentials and by creating a device-specific credential that a biometric or PIN-based user gesture protects.

segment.source: 2 What is Microsoft Passport?
segment.target: 2 What is Microsoft Passport?

segment.source: 2.1 What is Windows Hello?
segment.target: 2.1 What is Windows Hello?

segment.source: Windows Hello is the name Microsoft has given to the new biometric sign-in system built into Windows 10.
segment.target: Windows Hello is the name Microsoft has given to the new biometric sign-in system built into Windows 10.

segment.source: Because it is built directly into the operating system, Windows Hello allows face or fingerprint identification to unlock users’ devices.
segment.target: Because it is built directly into the operating system, Windows Hello allows face or fingerprint identification to unlock users’ devices.

segment.source: Authentication happens when the user supplies his or her unique biometric identifier to access the device-specific Microsoft Passport credentials, which means that an attacker who steals the device can’t log on to it unless that attacker has the PIN.
segment.target: Authentication happens when the user supplies his or her unique biometric identifier to access the device-specific Microsoft Passport credentials, which means that an attacker who steals the device can’t log on to it unless that attacker has the PIN.

segment.source: The Windows secure credential store protects biometric data on the device.
segment.target: The Windows secure credential store protects biometric data on the device.

segment.source: By using Windows Hello to unlock a device, the authorized user gains access to all of his or her Windows experience, apps, data, websites, and services.
segment.target: By using Windows Hello to unlock a device, the authorized user gains access to all of his or her Windows experience, apps, data, websites, and services.

segment.source: The Windows Hello authenticator is known as a Hello.
segment.target: The Windows Hello authenticator is known as a Hello.

segment.source: A Hello is unique to the combination of an individual device and a specific user.
segment.target: A Hello is unique to the combination of an individual device and a specific user.

segment.source: It does not roam across devices, is not shared with a server or calling app, and cannot easily be extracted from a device.
segment.target: It does not roam across devices, is not shared with a server or calling app, and cannot easily be extracted from a device.

segment.source: If multiple users share a device, each user needs to set up his or her own account.
segment.target: If multiple users share a device, each user needs to set up his or her own account.

segment.source: Every account gets a unique Hello for that device.
segment.target: Every account gets a unique Hello for that device.

segment.source: You can think of a Hello as a token you can use to unlock (or release) a stored credential.
segment.target: You can think of a Hello as a token you can use to unlock (or release) a stored credential.

segment.source: The Hello itself does not authenticate you to an app or service, but it releases credentials that can.
segment.target: The Hello itself does not authenticate you to an app or service, but it releases credentials that can.

segment.source: In other words, the Hello is not a user credential but it is a second factor for Microsoft Passport.
segment.target: In other words, the Hello is not a user credential but it is a second factor for Microsoft Passport.

segment.source: 2.2 What is Microsoft Passport?
segment.target: 2.2 What is Microsoft Passport?

segment.source: Windows Hello provides a robust way for a device to recognize an individual user, which addresses the first part of the path between a user and a requested service or data item.
segment.target: Windows Hello provides a robust way for a device to recognize an individual user, which addresses the first part of the path between a user and a requested service or data item.

segment.source: After the device has recognized the user, it still must authenticate the user before determining whether to grant access to a requested resource.
segment.target: After the device has recognized the user, it still must authenticate the user before determining whether to grant access to a requested resource.

segment.source: Microsoft Passport provides strong 2FA that is fully integrated into Windows and replaces reusable passwords with the combination of a specific device, and a biometric gesture or PIN.
segment.target: Microsoft Passport provides strong 2FA that is fully integrated into Windows and replaces reusable passwords with the combination of a specific device, and a biometric gesture or PIN.

segment.source: Microsoft Passport is not just a replacement for traditional 2FA systems, though.
segment.target: Microsoft Passport is not just a replacement for traditional 2FA systems, though.

segment.source: It is conceptually similar to smart cards: authentication is performed by using cryptographic primitives instead of string comparisons, and the user’s key material is secure inside tamper-resistant hardware.
segment.target: It is conceptually similar to smart cards: authentication is performed by using cryptographic primitives instead of string comparisons, and the user’s key material is secure inside tamper-resistant hardware.

segment.source: Microsoft Passport does not require the extra infrastructure components required for smart card deployment, either.
segment.target: Microsoft Passport does not require the extra infrastructure components required for smart card deployment, either.

segment.source: In particular, you do not need a Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) to manage certificates, if you do not currently have one.
segment.target: In particular, you do not need a Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) to manage certificates, if you do not currently have one.

segment.source: Microsoft Passport combines the major advantages of smart cards—deployment flexibility for virtual smart cards and robust security for physical smart cards—without any of their drawbacks.
segment.target: Microsoft Passport combines the major advantages of smart cards—deployment flexibility for virtual smart cards and robust security for physical smart cards—without any of their drawbacks.

segment.source: 2.3 How Microsoft Passport works
segment.target: 2.3 How Microsoft Passport works

segment.source: When the user sets up Microsoft Passport on his or her machine, Microsoft Passport generates a new public–private key pair on the device.
segment.target: When the user sets up Microsoft Passport on his or her machine, Microsoft Passport generates a new public–private key pair on the device.

segment.source: The TPM generates and protects this private key.
segment.target: The TPM generates and protects this private key.

segment.source: If the device does not have a TPM, the private key is encrypted and protected by software.
segment.target: If the device does not have a TPM, the private key is encrypted and protected by software.

segment.source: In addition TPM-enabled devices generate a block of data that that can be used to attest that a key is bound to TPM.
segment.target: In addition TPM-enabled devices generate a block of data that that can be used to attest that a key is bound to TPM.

segment.source: This attestation information can be used in your solution to decide if the user is granted a different authorization level for example.
segment.target: This attestation information can be used in your solution to decide if the user is granted a different authorization level for example.

segment.source: To enable Microsoft Passport on a device, the user must have either their Azure Active Directory account or Microsoft Account connected in Windows settings.
segment.target: To enable Microsoft Passport on a device, the user must have either their Azure Active Directory account or Microsoft Account connected in Windows settings.

segment.source: 2.3.1 How keys are protected
segment.target: 2.3.1 How keys are protected

segment.source: Any time key material is generated, it must be protected against attack.
segment.target: Any time key material is generated, it must be protected against attack.

segment.source: The most robust way to do this is through specialized hardware.
segment.target: The most robust way to do this is through specialized hardware.

segment.source: There is a long history of using hardware security modules (HSMs) to generate, store, and process keys for security-critical applications.
segment.target: There is a long history of using hardware security modules (HSMs) to generate, store, and process keys for security-critical applications.

segment.source: Smart cards are a special type of HSM, as are devices that are compliant with the Trusted Computing Group TPM standard.
segment.target: Smart cards are a special type of HSM, as are devices that are compliant with the Trusted Computing Group TPM standard.

segment.source: Wherever possible, the Microsoft Passport implementation takes advantage of onboard TPM hardware to generate, store, and process keys.
segment.target: Wherever possible, the Microsoft Passport implementation takes advantage of onboard TPM hardware to generate, store, and process keys.

segment.source: However, Microsoft Passport and Microsoft Passport for Work do not require an onboard TPM.
segment.target: However, Microsoft Passport and Microsoft Passport for Work do not require an onboard TPM.

segment.source: Whenever feasible, Microsoft recommends the use of TPM hardware.
segment.target: Whenever feasible, Microsoft recommends the use of TPM hardware.

segment.source: The TPM protects against a variety of known and potential attacks, including PIN brute-force attacks.
segment.target: The TPM protects against a variety of known and potential attacks, including PIN brute-force attacks.

segment.source: The TPM provides an additional layer of protection after an account lockout as well.
segment.target: The TPM provides an additional layer of protection after an account lockout as well.

segment.source: When the TPM has locked the key material, the user must reset the PIN.
segment.target: When the TPM has locked the key material, the user must reset the PIN.

segment.source: Resetting the PIN means that all keys and certificates encrypted with the old key material will be removed.
segment.target: Resetting the PIN means that all keys and certificates encrypted with the old key material will be removed.

segment.source: 2.3.2 Authentication
segment.target: 2.3.2 Authentication

segment.source: When a user wants to access protected key material, the authentication process begins with the user entering a PIN or biometric gesture to unlock the device, a process sometimes called "releasing the key".
segment.target: When a user wants to access protected key material, the authentication process begins with the user entering a PIN or biometric gesture to unlock the device, a process sometimes called "releasing the key".

segment.source: An application can never use the keys from another application, nor can someone ever use the keys from another user.
segment.target: An application can never use the keys from another application, nor can someone ever use the keys from another user.

segment.source: These keys are used to sign requests that are sent to the identity provider or IDP, seeking access to specified resources.
segment.target: These keys are used to sign requests that are sent to the identity provider or IDP, seeking access to specified resources.

segment.source: Applications can use specific APIs to request operations that require key material for particular actions.
segment.target: Applications can use specific APIs to request operations that require key material for particular actions.

segment.source: Access through these APIs does require explicit validation through a user gesture, and the key material is not exposed to the requesting application.
segment.target: Access through these APIs does require explicit validation through a user gesture, and the key material is not exposed to the requesting application.

segment.source: Rather, the application asks for a specific action like signing a piece of data, and the Microsoft Passport layer handles the actual work and returns the results.
segment.target: Rather, the application asks for a specific action like signing a piece of data, and the Microsoft Passport layer handles the actual work and returns the results.

segment.source: AIK
segment.target: AIK

segment.source: An attestation identity key is used to provide such a cryptographic proof (TPM key attestation) by signing the properties of the non-migratable key and providing the properties and signature to the relying party for verification.
segment.target: An attestation identity key is used to provide such a cryptographic proof (TPM key attestation) by signing the properties of the non-migratable key and providing the properties and signature to the relying party for verification.

segment.source: The resulting signature is called an “attestation statement.”
segment.target: The resulting signature is called an “attestation statement.”

segment.source: Since the signature is created using the AIK private key—which can only be used in the TPM that created it—the relying party can trust that the attested key is truly non-migratable and cannot be used outside that TPM.
segment.target: Since the signature is created using the AIK private key—which can only be used in the TPM that created it—the relying party can trust that the attested key is truly non-migratable and cannot be used outside that TPM.

segment.source: AIK Certificate
segment.target: AIK Certificate

segment.source: An AIK certificate is used to attest to the presence of an AIK within a TPM.
segment.target: An AIK certificate is used to attest to the presence of an AIK within a TPM.

segment.source: It is also used to attest that other keys certified by the AIK originated from that particular TPM.
segment.target: It is also used to attest that other keys certified by the AIK originated from that particular TPM.

segment.source: IDP
segment.target: IDP

segment.source: An IDP is an identity provider.
segment.target: An IDP is an identity provider.

segment.source: An example is the IDP build by Microsoft for Microsoft Accounts.
segment.target: An example is the IDP build by Microsoft for Microsoft Accounts.

segment.source: Every time an application needs to authenticate with an MSA, it can call the MSA IDP.
segment.target: Every time an application needs to authenticate with an MSA, it can call the MSA IDP.

segment.target: PKI

segment.source: Public key infrastructure is commonly used to point to an environment hosted by an organization itself and being responsible for creating keys, revoking keys, etc.
segment.target: Public key infrastructure is commonly used to point to an environment hosted by an organization itself and being responsible for creating keys, revoking keys, etc.

segment.source: TPM
segment.target: TPM

segment.source: The trusted platform module can be used to create cryptographic public/private key pairs in such a way that the private key can never be revealed or used outside the TPM (that is, the key is non-migratable).
segment.target: The trusted platform module can be used to create cryptographic public/private key pairs in such a way that the private key can never be revealed or used outside the TPM (that is, the key is non-migratable).

segment.source: TPM Key Attestation
segment.target: TPM Key Attestation

segment.source: A protocol that cryptographically proves that a key is TPM-bound.
segment.target: A protocol that cryptographically proves that a key is TPM-bound.

segment.source: This type of attestation can be used to guarantee that a certain cryptographic operation occurred in the TPM of a particular computer
